document_title: Over-activation of iNKT cells aggravate lung injury in bronchopulmonary dysplasia mice
summary_full: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease in preterm infants, characterized by abnormal proliferation and differentiation of alveolar type II epithelial cells (AEC II). This study investigated the role of invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells in BPD using public datasets, clinical samples, a hyperoxia-induced BPD mouse model, and an AEC II-iNKT cell co-culture system. The study found that IL-15, a factor for NKT cell development, increased in BPD patients. Clinically, peripheral blood NKT cells were elevated in BPD patients. In the mouse model, iNKT cell percentage and activation increased under hyperoxia, correlating with abnormal lung development. Inhibiting iNKT cells with anti-CD1d antibody alleviated lung injury, while activating them with α-GalCer or adoptive transfer of iNKT cells aggravated it. In vitro, iNKT cells worsened AEC II dysfunction under hyperoxia, leading to abnormal SP-C and T1α expression. RNA-seq analysis revealed that iNKT cells promoted ferroptosis in AEC II under hyperoxia, evidenced by increased ferroptosis-related gene expression and markers. This ferroptosis was accompanied by decreased SP-C and T1α expression, suggesting that iNKT cell recruitment and over-activation contribute to alveolarization disorder in BPD.
key_findings: Invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells are increased and activated in the peripheral blood of patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD).
Hyperoxia exposure in mice leads to increased accumulation and activation of iNKT cells in the lungs, correlating with abnormal lung development.
Inhibition of iNKT cell activation alleviates lung injury and improves alveolar development in a hyperoxia-induced BPD mouse model.
Specific activation or adoptive transfer of iNKT cells exacerbates lung injury and abnormal development in BPD mice.
iNKT cells promote ferroptosis in alveolar type II epithelial cells (AEC II) under hyperoxia, leading to decreased expression of AEC II and AEC I markers (SP-C and T1α).
The recruitment and over-activation of iNKT cells in the lung may be a significant cause of alveolarization disorder in BPD.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific mechanisms by which iNKT cells induce ferroptosis in AEC II.
Exploring the role of iNKT cells in the interaction with pulmonary microvascular endothelial cells in BPD.
Developing therapeutic strategies targeting iNKT cells for the treatment of BPD.
Utilizing lineage tracing and αGalCer/CD1d tetramers for more precise analysis of iNKT cell function and differentiation in BPD.
Examining the potential involvement of iNKT cells in the transdifferentiation of AEC II into mesenchymal-like cells.

conclusions: This study demonstrates that over-activation of iNKT cells exacerbates lung injury in a mouse model of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Hyperoxia leads to increased iNKT cell recruitment and activation in the lungs, which in turn promotes ferroptosis in alveolar type II epithelial cells (AEC II). This ferroptosis is associated with impaired AEC II differentiation (decreased SP-C and T1α expression), ultimately contributing to alveolarization disorder and the development of BPD. Targeting iNKT cells may offer a therapeutic avenue for BPD.
impact_statement: This research identifies over-activated iNKT cells as a key driver of lung injury in bronchopulmonary dysplasia by inducing ferroptosis in alveolar epithelial cells, suggesting a novel therapeutic target for this severe neonatal lung disease.
